reference_contexts: ['<1-hop>\n\nMUST SEE: 2.1 Railway Station. It is on Monastiriou Street which is renamed at some point Egnatia Street (see p. 34). Construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951, but it was officially 66. Vardariou Tower (Top Hane). 67. Old steam engine fronting Thessaloniki’s Railway Station.']
response:
The Railway Station on Monastiriou Street in Thessaloniki holds significant historical importance as a key transportation hub in the city. Construction of the station began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951, marking a pivotal development in Thessaloniki's transportation infrastructure. This station not only serves as a gateway for domestic and international travel but also symbolizes the city’s connectivity and modernization post-World War II.

Historically, the station has facilitated the movement of people and goods, contributing to Thessaloniki's role as a major commercial and cultural center in the region. It connects various suburbs and neighboring areas, enhancing accessibility for both locals and visitors. The station's strategic location on Monastiriou Street, which transitions into Egnatia Street, underscores its importance as a central artery in the city’s transport network.

In addition to its functional role, the Railway Station is surrounded by historical sites and neighborhoods, making it an ideal starting point for sightseeing. Nearby attractions include sections of the city’s west walls and Byzantine monuments, allowing travelers to immerse themselves in Thessaloniki's rich history. The area around the station is also home to various hotels, shops, and cafés, providing a vibrant atmosphere for visitors.

For those interested in local culture and history, the Railway Station offers an opportunity to engage with the city's past while enjoying modern amenities. Its architectural design and historical significance make it an Instagrammable spot, appealing to travelers seeking memorable experiences. Overall, the Railway Station on Monastiriou Street is not just a transit point but a landmark that encapsulates Thessaloniki's historical evolution and its ongoing relevance in contemporary transportation.
reference: The Railway Station on Monastiriou Street, which was renamed Egnatia Street, holds historical significance as its construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951. This station is a key part of Thessaloniki's transportation infrastructure, symbolizing the city's connectivity and development in the mid-20th century. Additionally, it features an old steam engine in front, which adds to its historical charm and reflects the evolution of transportation in the region.

reference_contexts: ['<1-hop>\n\n34 1 EGNATIA STREET This central avenue has been there practically since Thessaloniki’s founding, as it is a section of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd c. BC, and connected Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern day Albania) with Constantinople. It starts at Dimokratia square (see p. 58) and ends at the TIF grounds (see p. 31) and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, splitting in two the town’s historic centre. It is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style dating to the early 20th c. (mostly old hotels) that are absolutely worth observing, as well as some of the city’s most important monuments. MUST SEE: 1.1 Kolomvou Square. The crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street is indeed a bustling one! It was named after G. Colombo, an Italian who opened a hotel there in the early 20th century. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:']
response:
Egnatia Street holds significant historical importance as it has been a central thoroughfare in Thessaloniki since the city’s founding. Originally constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC, it connected the ancient port of Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës in Albania) to Constantinople. This avenue not only serves as a vital link through the city but also splits Thessaloniki's historic center, making it a bustling area rich in culture and architecture.

Along Egnatia Street, you will find several notable sites that reflect the city's diverse history and vibrant atmosphere. One of the must-see locations is Kolomvou Square, a lively crossroads where Egnatia meets Antigonidon Street. This area is known for its Kolomvou Archway, which has become a popular leisure hub filled with cafés, bars, and restaurants, perfect for enjoying local cuisine and socializing.

Another significant site is the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, which showcases the city’s Ottoman heritage. The mosque is a testament to the architectural influences that have shaped Thessaloniki over the centuries.

As you explore further, you will encounter the Railway Station on Monastiriou Street, which transitions into Egnatia Street. This station, operational since 1951, is a historical landmark that connects visitors to various destinations.

The historic center along Egnatia Street is also characterized by its eclectic and art deco buildings, primarily from the early 20th century, including old hotels that are worth observing for their architectural beauty. 

Overall, Egnatia Street is not just a route through Thessaloniki; it is a vibrant corridor filled with historical significance and cultural experiences, making it an ideal spot for sightseeing and capturing Instagrammable moments.
reference: Egnatia Street is historically significant as it has been a central avenue since the founding of Thessaloniki, being part of the Roman road constructed in the 2nd century BC that connected Dyrrhachium with Constantinople. This street splits the town’s historic centre and is a busy shopping area featuring remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style from the early 20th century. Notable sites along Egnatia Street include Kolomvou Square, a bustling crossroads with cafés and restaurants, and the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, which is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle. The mosque is currently undergoing renovations to house an exhibition of archaeological finds.

response:
Egnatia Street is a historic avenue in Thessaloniki, tracing its origins back to the Roman era in the 2nd century BC. It was part of a vital road that connected Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës in Albania) to Constantinople. This central thoroughfare has played a significant role in the city’s development, effectively splitting the historic center and serving as a bustling shopping area filled with eclectic and art deco architecture from the early 20th century.

As a first-time visitor, you’ll find several must-see places along Egnatia Street:

1. **Kolomvou Square**: This lively crossroads is where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street. It features the Kolomvou Archway, surrounded by cafés, bars, and restaurants, making it a perfect spot to relax and soak in the local atmosphere.

2. **Hamza Bey Mosque**: Built in 1467, this mosque is a significant historical site that reflects the city’s Ottoman heritage. It’s located near Egnatia Street and is worth a visit for its architectural beauty.

3. **Aristotelous Street**: At the western end of Egnatia, this pedestrianized boulevard is lined with shops and cafés, leading to the waterfront. It’s an ideal place for leisurely strolls and photography, especially during summer.

4. **Electra Palace Hotel and Olympion**: These iconic buildings showcase the monumental architectural style of Thessaloniki. Olympion is now the venue for the Thessaloniki Film Festival, making it a cultural hotspot.

5. **Modiano Market**: Located just off Egnatia Street, this historic market is a vibrant place to explore local food and products, offering a taste of Thessaloniki’s culinary scene.

Egnatia Street is not only a pathway through history but also a vibrant hub of activity, perfect for sightseeing and experiencing the local culture.
reference: Egnatia Street is a central avenue in Thessaloniki that has been present since the city's founding, originally constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC. It connected Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës in Albania) with Constantinople. The street starts at Dimokratia Square and ends at the TIF grounds and Aristotle University, dividing the historic center of the town. Along Egnatia Street, there are several must-see places, including Kolomvou Square, which is a bustling crossroads named after G. Colombo, an Italian hotelier. Another notable site is the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, which is unique for its peristyle and has undergone renovations to house an exhibition of archaeological finds.

The crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street is indeed a bustling one! It was named after G. Colombo, an Italian who opened a hotel there in the early 20th century. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:']
response:
Egnatia Street is a historically significant avenue in Thessaloniki, tracing its origins back to the 2nd century BC when it was part of a Roman road connecting Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës, Albania) to Constantinople. This central thoroughfare has been a vital artery for the city since its founding, effectively splitting Thessaloniki's historic center and serving as a bustling shopping area filled with eclectic and art deco architecture from the early 20th century.

Notable landmarks along Egnatia Street include:

1. **Kolomvou Square**: This lively crossroads where Egnatia meets Antigonidon Street is a hub of activity, featuring the Kolomvou Archway, which is surrounded by cafés, bars, and restaurants, making it a perfect spot for socializing and enjoying local cuisine.

2. **Hamza Bey Mosque**: Built in 1467, this mosque is a significant historical site, reflecting the city's Ottoman heritage.

3. **Aristotle University of Thessaloniki**: Located at the eastern end of Egnatia, this prominent university is a key educational institution in Greece.

4. **Dimokratia Square**: The starting point of Egnatia Street, this square is a focal point for local gatherings and events.

5. **Various Eclectic Buildings**: Along the avenue, you can observe numerous remarkable buildings that showcase the city’s architectural diversity, including old hotels and commercial establishments that contribute to the vibrant atmosphere.

Egnatia Street not only offers a glimpse into Thessaloniki's rich history but also provides an engaging experience for visitors interested in sightseeing, local culture, and photography. The blend of historical significance and modern-day vibrancy makes it an essential stop for anyone exploring the city.
reference: Egnatia Street is historically significant as it has been a central avenue since the founding of Thessaloniki, originally constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC. It connected Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës, Albania) with Constantinople. Along this busy shopping area, notable landmarks include Kolomvou Square, which features the Kolomvou Archway, a leisure hub with cafés and restaurants, and the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, which is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle. The mosque is currently undergoing renovations to house an exhibition of archaeological finds from metro excavations.

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. response:
Kalamaria is a vibrant suburb of Thessaloniki, known for its picturesque waterfront and lively atmosphere. Key attractions include Aretsou-Krini beach, which features a marina, open-air cinema, and numerous café-bars and fish tavernas along N. Plastira Street. This area is perfect for leisurely strolls and enjoying local cuisine, making it ideal for a solo traveler seeking familiar experiences. The pedestrian-friendly Komninon Street is another highlight, lined with shops, cafés, and restaurants, and home to the central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are located.

In contrast, Panorama, located about 10 km northeast of Thessaloniki, offers a more tranquil and nature-oriented experience. Nestled on Mt. Chortiatis, it is known for its hiking trails and scenic views. The area is rich in history, with remnants of a Byzantine aqueduct and the Vlatadon Monastery, making it appealing for those interested in cultural exploration. Panorama's charm lies in its lush greenery and outdoor activities, such as mountain biking and off-roading, which may attract visitors looking for adventure.

While Kalamaria is bustling and ideal for social interactions, especially with its lively cafés and restaurants, Panorama provides a peaceful retreat with opportunities for hiking and enjoying nature. For a weekend stay in summer, Kalamaria offers a more vibrant atmosphere with easy access to the beach and local nightlife, while Panorama is suited for those who prefer a quieter, nature-focused getaway. Both suburbs have their unique appeal, catering to different preferences, but Kalamaria stands out for its accessibility to social experiences and local culture.
reference: In Kalamaria, the main attractions include the seafront areas of Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and a marina with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a lively spot year-round. Additionally, Komninon Street, which is pedestrian-only, hosts shops, cafés, and restaurants, along with the central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are located. In contrast, Panorama, situated 12 km south of Thessaloniki, offers a panoramic view of the city and is characterized by luxury villas and a small shopping area. It is known for its natural attractions like Platanakia, a wooded ravine with a small zoo and a café, and a path leading to an artificial lake with scenic spots along the way.

65 SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS 2.4 Aretsou – Krini. These two most popular areas of Kalamaria stretch along the seafront. The facilities of the local marine sports club are here, next to Aretsou-Krini beach; there is also an open air cinema and a marina (the only one in town) with a 242-berth capacity (there are power, water and telephone services). The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas which get filled to capacity all year round. 2.5 Komninon Street. The longest part of the town’s main street is for pedestrian use only and you will find shops, cafés, small bars and restaurants along the way. This is also where you will find the area’s central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are. From the direction of the seafront, you can reach the area via I. Passalidis Street. How to get there. Bus lines 5 and 5A leave from Eleftherias square. Get off at Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at Chamodrakas stop in Aretsou area. 3', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. response:
Kalamaria is a vibrant suburb of Thessaloniki, known for its picturesque waterfront and lively atmosphere. Key attractions include the seafront areas of Aretsou and Krini, which feature a marina, open-air cinema, and numerous café-bars and fish tavernas. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is particularly popular, offering a range of dining and leisure options that attract both locals and visitors year-round. The area is also home to the central square, where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are located, providing a cultural touchpoint for exploration.

In contrast, Panorama, located approximately 10 km northeast of Thessaloniki, is characterized by its natural beauty and outdoor activities. Nestled on Mt. Chortiatis, it offers hiking trails, mountain biking, and off-roading opportunities, making it ideal for those who enjoy nature and adventure. The suburb is also historically significant, as it has been a source of water supply since Roman times, with remnants of a Byzantine aqueduct visible at its borders.

While Kalamaria is more urban and bustling, perfect for socializing and enjoying local cuisine, Panorama provides a serene escape with a focus on outdoor activities and scenic views. For a first-time visitor, Kalamaria offers a lively atmosphere with plenty of Instagrammable spots along the waterfront, making it a great choice for leisure and social interaction. Meanwhile, Panorama appeals to those seeking a blend of history and nature, ideal for a day trip filled with exploration and relaxation. Both suburbs showcase different facets of Thessaloniki, catering to diverse interests and experiences.
reference: Kalamaria is known for its popular areas along the seafront, particularly Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and a marina with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a vibrant spot year-round. In contrast, Panorama, located 12 km south of Thessaloniki, offers a panoramic view of the city and is characterized by luxury villas and a small shopping area. While Kalamaria is bustling with seaside activities, Panorama provides a more tranquil environment with natural attractions like Platanakia, a wooded ravine with a small zoo and a café.

user_input: What are the main attractions and facilities in Kalamaria, and how does it compare to the suburb of Panorama in Thessaloniki?

['65
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
2.4  Aretsou – Krini.
These two most popular 
areas of Kalamaria stretch 
along the seafront. The 
facilities of the local marine 
sports club are here, next to 
Aretsou-Krini beach; there is 
also an open air cinema and a 
marina (the only one in town) 
with a 242-berth capacity 
(there are power, water and 
telephone services). The 
waterfront N. Plastira Street  
is lined with café-bars and 
fish tavernas which get filled 
to capacity all year round.
2.5  Komninon Street.
The longest part of the 
town’s main street is for 
pedestrian use only and you 
will find shops, cafés, small 
bars and restaurants along 
the way. This is also where 
you will find the area’s central 
square where the Town 
Hall and the church of the 
Transfiguration of Christ are. 
From the direction of the 
seafront, you can reach the 
area via I. Passalidis Street. 
How to get there. Bus 
lines 5 and 5A leave from 
Eleftherias square. Get off at 
Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] 
stop or at Chamodrakas stop 
in Aretsou area.', '66
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
3.1  Chortiatis.
Named after the mountain, 
this small suburb on Mt 
Chortiatis (elev.: 1,201 m.), 
stretches approx. 10 km NE  
of Panorama. Since the Roman 
times, Thessaloniki’s water 
supply came from this place 
via Vlatadon Monastery (see 
p. 44); this is why you will 
see fragments of a Byzantine 
aqueduct at the suburb’s 
border. The mountain is covered 
with chestnut, oak, beech and 
fir trees, there is a mountain 
refuge (Kissos location, elev. 
1,201 m.) and it is the ideal 
place for hiking (there are 32 
charted paths), for mountain 
biking and off-roading.
How to get there. Board 
the 58 bus on Egnatia Street 
and get off at Dimarchio 
[Town Hall], Astynomia [Police 
Station] or at Platanakia stop.
4 	THERMI
This suburb is located a bit 
further away from town (15 km 
SE of the city centre) and more 
or less still keeps a countryside 
air about it. On-site excavations 
have shown that this was the 
location of the harbour of 
ancient Thermi, a major one  
in antiquity. The place was also 
known for its hot springs – 
thermae – hence the name  
of the gulf (Thermaikos).', '95
gulf. You will find a marine 
sports and a beach volleyball 
facility on Asprovalta beach 
(10 km long and awarded a 
Blue Flag) and on Nea Vrasna 
beach; Stavros is the biggest 
harbour in the gulf. Vrasna 
and Ano Stavros villages 
are situated at the foot of 
Mt Kerdylia; their traditional 
architecture makes them 
absolutely worth visiting.
How to get there. From 
Thessaloniki, take the 83, 
83M or 83N bus line to reach 
Lagkadas. For the other areas, 
travel by coach. If you go 
by car, head for Panorama, 
Chortiatis and Agios Vasileios 
(to reach Lake Koroneia) 
and from that point go east 
towards Kavala (to visit Lake 
Volvi and the Strymonian gulf).
6 	PIKROLIMNI 
It is located in the 
neighbouring Kilkis regional 
unit, to the south. It is a 
shallow lake (covering a 
450-hectare area) and in 
the lake floor mud there are 
chemical combinations such 
as sulphides and nitric salts 
with healing and cosmetic 
properties known across the 
country - the concentration 
is three times higher than 
that in the Dead Sea. In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans.', '\x07Thessaloniki International Trade Fair (HELEXPO)
	71.	\x07Society for Macedonian Studies –  
National Theatre of Northern Greece	
	72.	Garden Theatre	
	73.	Royal Theatre	
	74.	Thessaloniki Concert Hall	
	75.	Vafopouleio Cultural Centre – Library	
	76.	Kalamaria Municipal Theatre

		SPORTS FACILITIES
	79.	Indoor Sports Hall (Byzantine Sports Club)	
	80.	\x07Alexandreio Sports Arena (Palais des Sports)
	81.	Kaftanzogleio stadium	
	82.	The National Swimming Pool	
	83.	Poseidonio Sports Centre	
	84.	Toumpa Football ground	
	85.	“Kleanthis Vikelidis” Football ground	
	86.	Kalamaria Football ground

		PUBLIC TRANSPORT
	89.	Long Distance Bus Station

	92.	Kapani (Vlali Marketplace)

SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
situated nearby. The small 
mounds in the field are ancient 
tombs; a Neolithic settlement 
was excavated in one of them 
with a cemetery dating to the 
Geometric and Archaic period. 
An impressive Macedonian 
tomb was also unearthed in 
Agios Athanasios area.
How to get there. Bus 
lines 40, 40A and 40K leave 
for Kalochori from the Railway 
Station Stop. If you travel by 
car, take the Athens direction 
on the national road and turn 
towards Kalochori.
2 	KALAMARIA
This is practically an eastward 
‘extension’ of Thessaloniki and 
the city’s best known suburb, 
stretching along the waterfront, 
with many green spaces and 
a self-contained shopping 
centre. The first inhabitants are 
recorded in the early 20th c. and 
during the 1920’s significant 
numbers of Greek refugee 
populations settled here and 
built their small houses. They 
came from Caucasus, Minor 
Asia and Pontus [modern- 
day northeast Turkey]. Today,  
despite the rising building trend  
in the area, several refugee 
houses remain, still keeping  
a flavour of times goneby.
MUST SEΕ: 
2.1  Sofouli Street
(see p. 53).
2.2  Kyverneio [Government 
House] (Little Palace).']

response:
Kalamaria is a vibrant suburb of Thessaloniki, known for its picturesque waterfront and lively atmosphere. Key attractions include Aretsou-Krini beach, which features a marina, open-air cinema, and numerous café-bars and fish tavernas along N. Plastira Street. This area is perfect for leisurely strolls and enjoying local cuisine, making it an ideal spot for a solo traveler seeking familiar experiences. The pedestrian-friendly Komninon Street is another highlight, lined with shops, cafés, and restaurants, and home to the central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are located.

In contrast, Panorama, located about 10 km northeast of Kalamaria, offers a more tranquil and nature-oriented experience. Nestled on Mt. Chortiatis, it is known for its hiking trails, mountain biking, and scenic views. The area is rich in history, with remnants of a Byzantine aqueduct and the Vlatadon Monastery. While Panorama provides a peaceful retreat with outdoor activities, it may lack the bustling social scene and immediate access to beach facilities that Kalamaria offers.

For a weekend visit in summer, Kalamaria's lively atmosphere and waterfront attractions make it a more suitable choice for budget-conscious travelers looking for social interactions and Instagrammable spots. The accessibility of local transportation, such as bus lines, makes it easy to explore both Kalamaria and Panorama. However, if you prefer a quieter environment with opportunities for hiking and nature appreciation, Panorama could be a worthwhile day trip from Kalamaria. Overall, Kalamaria stands out for its vibrant social scene and beach access, while Panorama offers a serene escape into nature.
reference: Kalamaria features popular areas such as Aretsou and Krini, which stretch along the seafront and include a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and a marina with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, while Komninon Street, the town's main pedestrian street, hosts shops, cafés, and restaurants, along with the central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are located. In contrast, Panorama, located 12 km south of Thessaloniki's city center, offers a panoramic view from the slope of Mt Chortiatis and is characterized by luxury villas and a small shopping area. It is known for its natural attractions like Platanakia, a wooded ravine with a small zoo and a café, and a path leading to an artificial lake with scenic spots along the way.

['110
Thessaloniki State 
Symphony Orchestra 
(T.S.S.O.). 
It was established in 1959 
as the Symphony Orchestra 
of Northern Greece; in 1969 
it acquired its present name 
and was brought under state 
control. It is considered as one 
of the best of its kind in Greece 
and its musicians (approx. 100) 
have performed in some of the 
best known Festivals and music 
stages in Greece and abroad. 
Concerts take place in the 
Thessaloniki Concert Hall. 
Information: 73, Nikis Ave.
tel.: 2310 257.900
website: www.tsso.gr
Summer (open-air) cinemas. 
This is yet another attraction 
for visitors. Screenings take 
place in gardens, and you can 
watch a film while sipping your 
drink or having a snack, against 
a backdrop of trees and flowers. 
Films are not dubbed; Greek 
subtitles are used instead.
SPORTS 
Thessaloniki has a long 
tradition in sports. In recent 
decades, major sports events 
have taken place in the city 
(finals of european football and 
basketball games, international 
track and  field events, a 
marathon race, the 2004 
Olympic Games, international 
beach volleyball tournaments 
etc). A variety of modern and 
well equipped facilities are open 
to those who wish to practice 
their favourite sport or relax 
during their stay in town. Here 
is a list of sports facilities:

(see p. 64) and, a bit further 
off, Peraia (see p. 67).   
Apart from the 
entertainment options, 
a host of artistic events 
get organised in the city 
throughout the entire

[Megaro] (see p. 52), the

(see p. 25), the Theatre of 
the Society for Macedonian

Dasous] and the Theatre

but not least, you can visit the 
International Film Festival, 
the Thessaloniki Book Fair, the

109), and other venues housing

private companies or city 
agencies.
Finally, the Thessaloniki 
Regency Casino is located 
at the 12th km on the 
Thessaloniki – Airport Road 
and is open around the clock.', '65

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Kalamaria, a vibrant suburb of Thessaloniki, offers a variety of attractions and facilities that can enhance your travel experience, especially during the summer months.

1. **Seafront Areas**: The Aretsou-Krini area features a beautiful seafront where you can enjoy the beach, relax at café-bars, and dine at fish tavernas. The waterfront is lively and perfect for leisurely strolls, making it an ideal spot for Instagrammable moments.

2. **Open-Air Cinema**: Experience the charm of watching films under the stars at the local open-air cinema. This unique setting allows you to enjoy a movie while sipping a drink amidst a backdrop of trees and flowers, providing a memorable evening out.

3. **Marine Sports Club**: If you're interested in water activities, the local marine sports club offers various options. You can engage in water sports or simply enjoy the marina, which is the only one in town and has a 242-berth capacity.

4. **Komninon Street**: This pedestrian-only street is lined with shops, cafés, and small bars, making it a great place to explore local culture and cuisine. The central square here features the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ, adding a cultural touch to your visit.

5. **Cultural Venues**: Kalamaria hosts several cultural venues, including the Kalamaria Municipal Theatre and the Forest Theatre. These venues often feature artistic events and performances, providing an opportunity to immerse yourself in the local arts scene.

6. **Public Transport**: Getting around Kalamaria is convenient, with bus lines connecting you to other parts of Thessaloniki. This accessibility allows you to explore the city easily while enjoying the local atmosphere.

These attractions and facilities in Kalamaria not only cater to your sightseeing interests but also provide opportunities for local interaction and cultural experiences, making your weekend getaway enjoyable and memorable.
reference: In Kalamaria, travelers can enjoy the seafront areas of Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and the only marina in town with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a vibrant spot year-round. Additionally, Komninon Street, the longest part of the town’s main street, is pedestrian-friendly and offers shops, cafés, and restaurants, along with the central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are located.

['66
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
3.1  Chortiatis.
Named after the mountain, 
this small suburb on Mt 
Chortiatis (elev.: 1,201 m.), 
stretches approx. 10 km NE  
of Panorama. Since the Roman 
times, Thessaloniki’s water 
supply came from this place 
via Vlatadon Monastery (see 
p. 44); this is why you will 
see fragments of a Byzantine 
aqueduct at the suburb’s 
border. The mountain is covered 
with chestnut, oak, beech and 
fir trees, there is a mountain 
refuge (Kissos location, elev. 
1,201 m.) and it is the ideal 
place for hiking (there are 32 
charted paths), for mountain 
biking and off-roading.
How to get there. Board 
the 58 bus on Egnatia Street 
and get off at Dimarchio 
[Town Hall], Astynomia [Police 
Station] or at Platanakia stop.
4 	THERMI
This suburb is located a bit 
further away from town (15 km 
SE of the city centre) and more 
or less still keeps a countryside 
air about it. On-site excavations 
have shown that this was the 
location of the harbour of 
ancient Thermi, a major one  
in antiquity. The place was also 
known for its hot springs – 
thermae – hence the name  
of the gulf (Thermaikos).', '64

mounds in the field are ancient 
tombs; a Neolithic settlement 
was excavated in one of them

Geometric and Archaic period. 
An impressive Macedonian 
tomb was also unearthed in 
Agios Athanasios area.
How to get there. Bus 
lines 40, 40A and 40K leave 
for Kalochori from the Railway 
Station Stop. If you travel by 
car, take the Athens direction 
on the national road and turn 
towards Kalochori.
2 	KALAMARIA
This is practically an eastward 
‘extension’ of Thessaloniki and 
the city’s best known suburb, 
stretching along the waterfront, 
with many green spaces and 
a self-contained shopping 
centre. The first inhabitants are 
recorded in the early 20th c. and 
during the 1920’s significant 
numbers of Greek refugee 
populations settled here and 
built their small houses. They 
came from Caucasus, Minor 
Asia and Pontus [modern- 
day northeast Turkey]. Today,  
despite the rising building trend  
in the area, several refugee 
houses remain, still keeping  
a flavour of times goneby.

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Kalamaria is a vibrant suburb of Thessaloniki, known for its picturesque waterfront and lively atmosphere. It features several key attractions, including the popular Aretsou-Krini area, which boasts a beach, a marina, and a local marine sports club. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it an ideal spot for dining and socializing. The area also has an open-air cinema, enhancing its appeal for leisure activities. The central square, home to the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ, is a cultural highlight and a great place to experience local life.

In contrast, Panorama, located approximately 10 km northeast of Kalamaria, offers a more tranquil and nature-oriented experience. Nestled on Mt. Chortiatis, it is known for its hiking trails, mountain biking opportunities, and scenic views. The area is rich in history, with remnants of a Byzantine aqueduct and the Vlatadon Monastery, which adds a cultural dimension to outdoor activities. While Panorama is ideal for those seeking adventure and natural beauty, Kalamaria caters more to those looking for a lively social scene and waterfront relaxation.

Both suburbs have their unique charm. Kalamaria is perfect for leisurely strolls along the coast, enjoying local cuisine, and engaging with the community, while Panorama appeals to outdoor enthusiasts and those interested in historical exploration. For a first-time visitor, Kalamaria offers a more accessible and familiar urban experience, while Panorama provides a refreshing escape into nature. Depending on your interests, both suburbs can complement a weekend itinerary in Thessaloniki, showcasing the diverse offerings of the city.
reference: Kalamaria is known for its popular areas along the seafront, such as Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and the only marina in town with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a vibrant area year-round. Additionally, Komninon Street, which is pedestrian-only, hosts shops, cafés, and the central square with the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ. Public transport is accessible via bus lines 5 and 5A. In contrast, Panorama, located 12 km south of Thessaloniki, offers a panoramic view of the city and is characterized by luxury villas and a small shopping area. It has historical significance, being settled by refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus in the early 20th century. A notable attraction in Panorama is Platanakia, a wooded ravine with a small zoo and a café, along with a 6 km path leading to an artificial lake, showcasing natural beauty and historical remnants like Byzantine watermills.

royal family; today the minister

the President of the Hellenic 
Republic stay here when 
visiting the city. The ground 
floor includes the lounges,  
a dance hall and an atrium;  
the first floor includes two 
suites and secondary rooms. 
It is surrounded by a garden 
and it affords an amazing 
view of the city as well as Mts 
Chortiatis and Olympus.
2.3  Kodra former military 
camp.
Building works are under way 
to change it into a park. The 
Municipality of Kalamaria often 
hosts cultural events and visual 
art exhibitions there. On-site 
excavations brought to light a 
settlement dating to the archaic 
and classical times (9th – 5th 
c. BC), which some scientists 
believe it is identified as the 
location of Ancient Thermi.
71.  
Kyverneio 
(Palataki) 
overlooks cape 
Karampournaki 
(Kalamaria).
72.  
Panorama 
area offers a 
fine view of 
the city and its 
environs.
71', '110
Thessaloniki State 
Symphony Orchestra 
(T.S.S.O.). 
It was established in 1959 
as the Symphony Orchestra 
of Northern Greece; in 1969 
it acquired its present name 
and was brought under state 
control. It is considered as one 
of the best of its kind in Greece 
and its musicians (approx. 100) 
have performed in some of the 
best known Festivals and music 
stages in Greece and abroad. 
Concerts take place in the 
Thessaloniki Concert Hall. 
Information: 73, Nikis Ave.
tel.: 2310 257.900
website: www.tsso.gr
Summer (open-air) cinemas. 
This is yet another attraction 
for visitors. Screenings take 
place in gardens, and you can 
watch a film while sipping your 
drink or having a snack, against 
a backdrop of trees and flowers. 
Films are not dubbed; Greek 
subtitles are used instead.
SPORTS 
Thessaloniki has a long 
tradition in sports. In recent 
decades, major sports events 
have taken place in the city 
(finals of european football and 
basketball games, international 
track and  field events, a 
marathon race, the 2004 
Olympic Games, international 
beach volleyball tournaments 
etc). A variety of modern and 
well equipped facilities are open 
to those who wish to practice 
their favourite sport or relax 
during their stay in town. Here 
is a list of sports facilities:
Kaftanzogleio National 
Stadium:  
Agiou Dimitriou St.', '96
Since Thessaloniki’s 
founding days and on account 
of its location, the town was 
always seen as a stopover 
place on the route used for 
East to West trading and vice 
versa. Today, the Thessaloniki 
town centre is the ideal 
destination for those who 
wish to add shopping to 
their travelling experience. 
The traditional roofed and 
open-air marketplaces are 
well known (see p. 21). You 
will find foodstuffs, spices, 
clothes, furniture and small 
objects in reasonable prices. 
Make a note of visiting Bit-
Pazar (see p. 36) the place 
where second-hand and 
antique dealers’ shops are  
to be found. 
The city’s modern 
commercial centre (see p. 27) 
is in the area encompassed by 
Aristotelous Street (see p. 15), 
the White Tower (see p. 24) 
and Tsimiski Street. You will 
find stylish clothing boutiques, 
department stores as well 
as decoration and fur shops. 
Visit also the Hirsch Building 
Mall (see p 20) and Plateia 
[Square] Mall (see p. 20). 
Other interesting shopping 
areas, for lower budgets, 
include Venizelou St. (see p. 
20), Egnatia St. (see p. 34) 
and Agiou Dimitriou St.

The area started to grow 
in the late 19th c., after the 
demolition of the eastern 
city walls and the adoption 
of the tramway (horse-drawn 
in 1893 and power-driven 
in 1907). Its first name 
was Exoches [meaning

its rural character, or the Villas 
quarter, as luxury residencies 
with large gardens began

situated nearby. The small 
mounds in the field are ancient

was excavated in one of them 
with a cemetery dating to the

['<1-hop>

65 SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS 2.4 Aretsou – Krini. These two most popular areas of Kalamaria stretch along the seafront. The facilities of the local marine sports club are here, next to Aretsou-Krini beach; there is also an open air cinema and a marina (the only one in town) with a 242-berth capacity (there are power, water and telephone services). The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas which get filled to capacity all year round. 2.5 Komninon Street. The longest part of the town’s main street is for pedestrian use only and you will find shops, cafés, small bars and restaurants along the way. This is also where you will find the area’s central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are. From the direction of the seafront, you can reach the area via I. Passalidis Street. How to get there. Bus lines 5 and 5A leave from Eleftherias square. Get off at Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at Chamodrakas stop in Aretsou area. 3', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Kalamaria, a charming suburb of Thessaloniki, offers a delightful blend of natural beauty, cultural experiences, and historical significance, making it an appealing destination for travelers.

One of the standout features of Kalamaria is its picturesque waterfront, which provides a scenic backdrop for leisurely strolls. The area is dotted with green spaces, perfect for relaxing or enjoying a picnic while soaking in the summer sun. The waterfront promenade is ideal for capturing Instagrammable moments, with stunning views of the sea and the city skyline.

Cultural enthusiasts will appreciate the Municipality of Kalamaria's commitment to the arts, as it frequently hosts cultural events and visual art exhibitions, particularly at the former Kodra military camp, which is being transformed into a park. This site not only offers a glimpse into the area's history but also serves as a vibrant space for community gatherings and artistic expression.

For those interested in history, Kalamaria is home to several notable landmarks. The Kyverneio, or Little Palace, is a must-see. Originally built as a royal residence, it now serves as the official residence for the minister of Macedonia-Thrace and the President of the Hellenic Republic during their visits. The building's architecture and surrounding gardens provide a beautiful setting for exploration.

Additionally, the area boasts archaeological significance, with excavations revealing ancient settlements that date back to the archaic and classical periods. This rich history adds depth to the travel experience, allowing visitors to connect with the past.

Kalamaria's blend of cultural events, historical sites, and natural beauty makes it a captivating destination for those seeking a leisurely weekend getaway. Whether you're enjoying the waterfront, exploring local art, or visiting historical landmarks, Kalamaria offers a unique and enriching experience for every traveler.
reference: Kalamaria is known for its vibrant seafront areas, particularly Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and the only marina in town with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a lively spot year-round. Additionally, Komninon Street, the longest part of the town’s main street, is pedestrian-friendly and hosts shops, cafés, and restaurants, along with the central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are located. Public transport is accessible via bus lines from Eleftherias square, making it easy for travelers to explore these attractions.

user_input: What are some popular areas in Kalamaria and how can you get there?
retrieved_contexts:
['65
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
2.4  Aretsou – Krini.
These two most popular 
areas of Kalamaria stretch 
along the seafront. The 
facilities of the local marine 
sports club are here, next to 
Aretsou-Krini beach; there is 
also an open air cinema and a 
marina (the only one in town) 
with a 242-berth capacity 
(there are power, water and 
telephone services). The 
waterfront N. Plastira Street  
is lined with café-bars and 
fish tavernas which get filled 
to capacity all year round.
2.5  Komninon Street.
The longest part of the 
town’s main street is for 
pedestrian use only and you 
will find shops, cafés, small 
bars and restaurants along 
the way. This is also where 
you will find the area’s central 
square where the Town 
Hall and the church of the 
Transfiguration of Christ are. 
From the direction of the 
seafront, you can reach the 
area via I. Passalidis Street. 
How to get there. Bus 
lines 5 and 5A leave from 
Eleftherias square. Get off at 
Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] 
stop or at Chamodrakas stop 
in Aretsou area.', 'In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans. There are 
swimming pools for men 
and women, 10 personal 
hydromassage areas where 
mineral spring water is used, 
saunas, a gym and areas 
for mud treatment. In the 
summer, visitors can enjoy 
a special mud therapy by 
the lake shore which gets 
usually dried up during the 
warmest season of the year. 
In the grounds you will find 
a physiotherapy centre and 
a medical clinic, a hotel, a 
restaurant, a bar, basketball 
and football fields.
How to get there. 
Pikrolimni is located 23 
km N of Thessaloniki. If 
you travel by car, follow the 
signs to Kilkis and after that, 
from Galliko village head 
for Xylokeratia (Pikrolimni). 
Alternatively there is a bus 
from Dimokratias square 
(Vardari) leaving daily at 9 am, 
which will take you to the Mud 
Therapy Centre for free.
DAY EXCURSIONS
114', 'The area was inhabited 
for the first time in 1923 
when refugees from Minor 
Asia settled here. Until then 
Peraia was the property of a 
Turkish Bey [a dignitary], Neoi 
Epivates was a Turkish estate 
(Bahçe Çiflik in Turkish) and 
Agia Triada was called White 
Fountain. Today, these areas 
have evolved into suburbs 
and seaside resorts. Along 
the entire waterfront you will 
find beaches, awarded the 
Blue Flag for beach quality, 
with facilities for water 
sports, beach volleyball and 
so on. There are fish tavernas, 
cafés and bars bordering 
the seafront pedestrian way, 
offering a fine seaview.
How to get there. You  
can take the buses Nos. 71 
and 71A for N. Michaniona 
from the Railway Station Stop 
in July and August (get off at  
any stop from Paralia Peraias  
to Agia Triada). Throughout  
the year, bus lines 02 and  
02A will get you to A.S. IKEA  
station where you can board  
any one of the 72, 72A, 72B  
74', '105
Hellenic Professional Yacht 
Owners Association:  
Marina Zeas  
(Administration Building), 
185 36 – Piraeus
tel.: 210 45.26.335
fax: 210 42.80.465
website: www.hpyoa.gr
MARINA
The Thessaloniki Marina is 
located in Aretsou Kalamaria, 
tel.: \x072310 444.598,  
2310 444.541  
(Port Authority)
fax: 2310 444.585 
VHF: Channel 9 (24-hour service) 
website:  
www.thessaloniki-marina.gr
BEACHES
Go for a swim in Aretsou beach 
(Kalamaria, see p. 64) and 
the nearby beaches of Peraia, 
Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see 
p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, 
Angelochori (see p. 68) and the 
beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). 
A bit farther away, you can try the 
beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea 
Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). 
At a 60 – 90 min. distance from 
the city you will reach the very 
popular and absolutely beautiful 
beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92).
MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS
Lagkadas Spa: 
Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki 
tel.', '98
NIGHTLIFE
facilities. During the summer 
months though, most of 
those clubs and venues move 
to open-air grounds in the 
airport area (see p. 106). 
Another favourite area to 
Thessalonians is Kalamaria 
(see p. 64) and, a bit further 
off, Peraia (see p. 67).   
Apart from the 
entertainment options, 
a host of artistic events 
get organised in the city 
throughout the entire 
year: choose among the 
Thessaloniki Concert Hall 
[Megaro] (see p. 52), the 
Vasiliko [Royal] Theatre  
(see p. 25), the Theatre of 
the Society for Macedonian 
Studies (see p. 25 & 109), 
Moni Lazariston (see p. 61),  
the Forest Theatre [Theatro 
Dasous] and the Theatre  
of the Earth [Theatro Gis] 
(see p. 48); or you can opt for a 
visit to museums (see p. 70-81) 
and smaller cultural venues. Last 
but not least, you can visit the 
International Film Festival, 
the Thessaloniki Book Fair, the 
Demetria Festival (see p. 108-
109), and other venues housing 
events on a smaller scale by  
private companies or city 
agencies.
Finally, the Thessaloniki 
Regency Casino is located 
at the 12th km on the 
Thessaloniki – Airport Road 
and is open around the clock.']

response:
Kalamaria is a vibrant suburb of Thessaloniki, known for its beautiful seafront and lively atmosphere. Two popular areas to explore are Aretsou-Krini and Komninon Street.

**Aretsou-Krini**: This area stretches along the waterfront and is famous for its beach, marina, and recreational facilities. You can enjoy a variety of café-bars and fish tavernas along N. Plastira Street, which is bustling year-round. The local marine sports club and an open-air cinema add to the charm of this seaside spot. To get there, you can take bus lines 5 or 5A from Eleftherias Square and disembark at the Naftikos Omilos (Marine Club) stop or at Chamodrakas stop in the Aretsou area.

**Komninon Street**: This pedestrian-only street is the longest part of the town’s main thoroughfare, lined with shops, cafés, and restaurants. It features the central square where you can find the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ. Accessing this area is easy; from the seafront, you can walk via I. Passalidis Street. 

Both areas offer a mix of local culture and leisure activities, making them ideal for sightseeing. The vibrant atmosphere, combined with the opportunity to interact with locals, enhances the experience. Whether you’re enjoying a meal by the sea or exploring the shops, Kalamaria provides a delightful glimpse into the local lifestyle. 

For a weekend visit in the summer, these areas are perfect for capturing Instagrammable moments while enjoying the local cuisine and culture.
reference: Some popular areas in Kalamaria include Aretsou and Krini, which stretch along the seafront and feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and a marina. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas. To get to these areas, you can take bus lines 5 and 5A from Eleftherias square and get off at the Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at Chamodrakas stop in the Aretsou area.

user_input: What are the key attractions and features of Kalamaria, and how does it compare to the suburb of Panorama in Thessaloniki?

['66
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
3.1  Chortiatis.
Named after the mountain, 
this small suburb on Mt 
Chortiatis (elev.: 1,201 m.), 
stretches approx. 10 km NE  
of Panorama. Since the Roman 
times, Thessaloniki’s water 
supply came from this place 
via Vlatadon Monastery (see 
p. 44); this is why you will 
see fragments of a Byzantine 
aqueduct at the suburb’s 
border. The mountain is covered 
with chestnut, oak, beech and 
fir trees, there is a mountain 
refuge (Kissos location, elev. 
1,201 m.) and it is the ideal 
place for hiking (there are 32 
charted paths), for mountain 
biking and off-roading.
How to get there. Board 
the 58 bus on Egnatia Street 
and get off at Dimarchio 
[Town Hall], Astynomia [Police 
Station] or at Platanakia stop.
4 	THERMI
This suburb is located a bit 
further away from town (15 km 
SE of the city centre) and more 
or less still keeps a countryside 
air about it. On-site excavations 
have shown that this was the 
location of the harbour of 
ancient Thermi, a major one  
in antiquity. The place was also 
known for its hot springs – 
thermae – hence the name  
of the gulf (Thermaikos).', '64
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
situated nearby. The small 
mounds in the field are ancient 
tombs; a Neolithic settlement 
was excavated in one of them 
with a cemetery dating to the 
Geometric and Archaic period. 
An impressive Macedonian 
tomb was also unearthed in 
Agios Athanasios area.
How to get there. Bus 
lines 40, 40A and 40K leave 
for Kalochori from the Railway 
Station Stop. If you travel by 
car, take the Athens direction 
on the national road and turn 
towards Kalochori.
2 	KALAMARIA
This is practically an eastward 
‘extension’ of Thessaloniki and 
the city’s best known suburb, 
stretching along the waterfront, 
with many green spaces and 
a self-contained shopping 
centre. The first inhabitants are 
recorded in the early 20th c. and 
during the 1920’s significant 
numbers of Greek refugee 
populations settled here and 
built their small houses. They 
came from Caucasus, Minor 
Asia and Pontus [modern- 
day northeast Turkey]. Today,  
despite the rising building trend  
in the area, several refugee 
houses remain, still keeping  
a flavour of times goneby.
MUST SEΕ: 
2.1  Sofouli Street
(see p. 53).

House] (Little Palace).', 'FERAIOU

72', '65
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
2.4  Aretsou – Krini.
These two most popular 
areas of Kalamaria stretch 
along the seafront. The 
facilities of the local marine 
sports club are here, next to 
Aretsou-Krini beach; there is 
also an open air cinema and a 
marina (the only one in town) 
with a 242-berth capacity 
(there are power, water and 
telephone services). The 
waterfront N. Plastira Street  
is lined with café-bars and 
fish tavernas which get filled 
to capacity all year round.
2.5  Komninon Street.
The longest part of the 
town’s main street is for 
pedestrian use only and you 
will find shops, cafés, small 
bars and restaurants along 
the way. This is also where 
you will find the area’s central 
square where the Town 
Hall and the church of the 
Transfiguration of Christ are. 
From the direction of the 
seafront, you can reach the 
area via I. Passalidis Street. 
How to get there. Bus 
lines 5 and 5A leave from 
Eleftherias square. Get off at 
Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] 
stop or at Chamodrakas stop 
in Aretsou area.', 'Another option for you 
is to go swimming in the 
beautiful beaches by the 
seaside suburbs and city 
outskirts (see p. 63-69), in 
places within the regional 
unit of Thessaloniki (see p. 
91-95), and in Halkidiki (see 
p. 92). You can also visit the 
Magic Park (12th km on the 
Thessaloniki – Airport Road), 
the biggest amusement park 
in Greece, which attracts 
children, teenagers, grown-
ups and families alike  
(www.magicpark.gr); the 
WaterLand is another 
fun option as there are 
waterpools, waterslides  
of various sizes, with different 
levels of difficulty, restaurants 
and mini markets. It is 
located in Tagarades,  
Thermi area, (see p. 66).

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. response:
Kalamaria is a vibrant suburb of Thessaloniki, known for its picturesque waterfront and lively atmosphere. Key attractions include the seafront areas of Aretsou and Krini, which feature a marina, open-air cinema, and numerous café-bars and fish tavernas. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is particularly popular, bustling with life year-round. The area also boasts a pedestrian-only main street, Komninon Street, lined with shops, cafés, and restaurants, making it ideal for leisurely strolls and social interactions. The central square, home to the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ, adds a cultural touch to the suburb.

In contrast, Panorama, located approximately 10 km northeast of Kalamaria, offers a more tranquil and nature-oriented experience. Nestled on Mt. Chortiatis, it is known for its hiking trails, mountain biking, and off-roading opportunities, with 32 charted paths available for outdoor enthusiasts. The area is rich in history, with remnants of a Byzantine aqueduct and the Vlatadon Monastery, which historically supplied water to Thessaloniki. The suburb's elevation provides stunning views of the city and surrounding landscapes, making it a great spot for sightseeing and photography.

While Kalamaria is ideal for those seeking a lively atmosphere with social interactions and dining experiences, Panorama caters to visitors looking for outdoor activities and a peaceful retreat. Both suburbs offer unique experiences: Kalamaria is perfect for enjoying local cuisine and vibrant street life, while Panorama is suited for nature lovers and those interested in historical exploration. For a weekend visit, Kalamaria may provide a more dynamic experience, while Panorama offers a refreshing escape into nature.
reference:
Kalamaria is known for its vibrant seafront areas, particularly Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and a marina with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a popular destination year-round. The main street, Komninon, is pedestrian-friendly and hosts shops, cafés, and the central square with the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ. Public transport is accessible via bus lines from Eleftherias square.

In contrast, Panorama, located 12 km south of Thessaloniki, offers a panoramic view of the city and is characterized by luxury villas and a small shopping area. It was uninhabited until the early 20th century, with its first inhabitants being refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Panorama is also known for its natural attractions, such as Platanakia, a wooded ravine with a small zoo and a café, and a 6 km path leading to an artificial lake with scenic spots along the way. Both areas provide unique experiences, with Kalamaria focusing on coastal activities and nightlife, while Panorama emphasizes residential luxury and natural beauty.

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. response:
Kalamaria, a vibrant suburb of Thessaloniki, offers a mix of attractions and facilities perfect for a weekend getaway. 

**Main Attractions:**

1. **Aretsou-Krini Beach**: This popular seafront area features a beach, a marina, and an open-air cinema, making it an ideal spot for relaxation and leisure activities. The marina is the only one in town, accommodating 242 boats with essential services.

2. **N. Plastira Street**: Lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, this waterfront street is perfect for enjoying local cuisine and socializing. It’s a lively area that attracts visitors year-round.

3. **Komninon Street**: This pedestrian-only street is the town’s main thoroughfare, filled with shops, cafés, and restaurants. Here, you can visit the central square, which houses the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ.

**Sports Facilities:**

Kalamaria is also home to several sports facilities, including:

- **Kaftanzogleio National Stadium**: A multi-purpose stadium located on Agiou Dimitriou St., ideal for sports enthusiasts.
- **Poseidonio Sports Centre**: Offers swimming pools and fields for various sports, located at N. Paralia & 25th Martiou St.
- **Thessaloniki National Swimming Pool**: Situated on Telloglou St., it’s perfect for swimming enthusiasts.

**Accessing Kalamaria:**

To reach Kalamaria, you can take bus lines 5 and 5A from Eleftherias Square. Get off at the Naftikos Omilos (Marine Club) stop or at Chamodrakas stop in the Aretsou area. The public transport system is efficient and user-friendly, making it easy to explore the attractions.

Kalamaria’s blend of cultural experiences, local cuisine, and recreational facilities makes it an excellent destination for leisure travelers looking to immerse themselves in the local atmosphere while enjoying picturesque spots perfect for photography.
reference: In Kalamaria, the main attractions include the seafront areas of Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and the only marina in town with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a lively spot year-round. Additionally, Komninon Street, which is pedestrian-only, hosts shops, cafés, and restaurants, along with the central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are located. To access these areas, bus lines 5 and 5A depart from Eleftherias square, with stops at Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] or Chamodrakas in the Aretsou area.

user_input: What are some popular beaches to visit in Chalkidiki, and how far are they from Thessaloniki?

['Such evidence 
makes this cave one of the 
oldest archaeological sites in 
Europe. Findings from the cave 
(tools, animal bones etc) are  
on display at the Museum  
and so are a cast of the skull  
(the original is kept at the 
Geology-Palaeontology Museum  
of the Aristotle University  
of Thessaloniki, see p. 38) and  
a reconstruction of the place  
it was found.
4.1  Halkidiki (also 
Chalcidice or Chalkidiki) – 
Agio Oros [Holy Mount].
Homeland of Aristotle,  
the ancient Greek philosopher, 
Halkidiki is one of the best 
and most popular tourist 
destinations in Greece with 
an important history, bustling 
tourist resorts, traditional 
villages, enchanting beaches, 
verdant mountains and an 
intense night life. Located 
south of Thessaloniki, 
Halkidiki ends in the three 
leg-shaped peninsulas named 
Kassandra, Sithonia and 
Athos. Thessalonians swarm 
in Kassandra and Sithonia for 
110.  
One of 
Halkidiki’s 
numerous 
lovely beaches.
111.  
Mount 
Athos: Agios 
Panteleimonas 
Monastery.
110', '95
gulf. You will find a marine 
sports and a beach volleyball 
facility on Asprovalta beach 
(10 km long and awarded a 
Blue Flag) and on Nea Vrasna 
beach; Stavros is the biggest 
harbour in the gulf. Vrasna 
and Ano Stavros villages 
are situated at the foot of 
Mt Kerdylia; their traditional 
architecture makes them 
absolutely worth visiting.
How to get there. From 
Thessaloniki, take the 83, 
83M or 83N bus line to reach 
Lagkadas. For the other areas, 
travel by coach. If you go 
by car, head for Panorama, 
Chortiatis and Agios Vasileios 
(to reach Lake Koroneia) 
and from that point go east 
towards Kavala (to visit Lake 
Volvi and the Strymonian gulf).
6 	PIKROLIMNI 
It is located in the 
neighbouring Kilkis regional 
unit, to the south. It is a 
shallow lake (covering a 
450-hectare area) and in 
the lake floor mud there are 
chemical combinations such 
as sulphides and nitric salts 
with healing and cosmetic 
properties known across the 
country - the concentration 
is three times higher than 
that in the Dead Sea. In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans.', '105

(Administration Building),

tel.: 210 45.26.335

MARINA
The Thessaloniki Marina is 
located in Aretsou Kalamaria,

2310 444.541  
(Port Authority)
fax: 2310 444.585 
VHF: Channel 9 (24-hour service) 
website:  
www.thessaloniki-marina.gr
BEACHES
Go for a swim in Aretsou beach 
(Kalamaria, see p. 64) and 
the nearby beaches of Peraia, 
Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see 
p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, 
Angelochori (see p. 68) and the 
beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). 
A bit farther away, you can try the 
beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea 
Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). 
At a 60 – 90 min. distance from 
the city you will reach the very 
popular and absolutely beautiful 
beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92).
MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS
Lagkadas Spa: 
Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki 
tel.', '85
DAY EXCURSIONS
Aravissou springs (15 km 
NW) where you can enjoy a 
meal at the local tavernas;  
the artificial Platanopotamos 
Lake, near Agrosykia village, 
(17 km NE) where you 
can visit the ruins of Pelit 
fortress, dating to the times 
of Alexander the Great, and 
Profitis Ilias country chapel; 
and the recreation area in 
Dytiko plane-tree forest (3.5 
km NE of Agrosykia village).
How to get there. Ancient 
Pella is located 40 km W of 
Thessaloniki. If you go by car, 
take the national road towards 
Edessa town and then follow 
the signs that will lead you 
to the archaeological site. To 
reach the military Museum of 
Balkan Wars, take the 68 bus 
departing from the station at 
the horseshoe-shaped point 
on Aristotelous Street (where 
Aristotelous and Egnatia 
Streets meet).
2 	\x07VERGINA  
(AIGES or AIGAI)
As far back as the 10th -8th 
c. BC Aiges was already a great  
town and the capital of the 
Macedon state until the 5th BC  
when King Archelaos moved 
the capital to Pella. It was 
situated in the centre of 
the area which was called 
“Macedonian Land” by 
Herodotus [an ancient Greek 
Historian].', 'IKEA station. 
If you travel by car, head for 
the airport and then follow 
Michanionas, Miaouli and 
Epanomis country roads.
7 	NEA MICHANIONA
A major fishing centre (32 
km S of Thessaloniki) with 
the largest fleet of deep sea 
fish boats in Greece! Once a 
refugee settlement, it is now a 
steadily growing area. The fish 
pier building by the picturesque 
harbour gets crowded especially 
during the early morning hours. 
Τhe seafront road is lined with 
café-bars and tavernas. Popular 
beaches in this area such as 
Tourbani and Angelochori have 
been awarded the Blue Flag  
for their beach quality.
MUST SEE:
7.1  Angelochori.
This small village lies 4 km  
N. of Nea Michaniona. 
Cape Megalo Emvolo (or 
Megalo Karampournou) 
affords a wonderful view of 
the Olympus massif. It is 
worth noticing the particular 
architectural structure of the 
remaining parts of an ottoman 
stronghold, built there in 1884 
by German civil engineers; 
there is also a lighthouse 
reaching a height of 10.50 m.  
75. Nea 
Michaniona 
is one of 
the greatest 
fisheries in 
Greece.
76. Peraia 
beach.
77. View of 
the seafront at 
Neoi Epivates.
78.']

105 Hellenic Professional Yacht Owners Association: Marina Zeas (Administration Building), 185 36 – Piraeus tel.: 210 45.26.335 fax: 210 42.80.465 website: www.hpyoa.gr MARINA The Thessaloniki Marina is located in Aretsou Kalamaria, tel.: \x072310 444.598, 2310 444.541 (Port Authority) fax: 2310 444.585 VHF: Channel 9 (24-hour service) website: www.thessaloniki-marina.gr BEACHES Go for a swim in Aretsou beach (Kalamaria, see p. 64) and the nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, Angelochori (see p. 68) and the beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). A bit farther away, you can try the beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). At a 60 – 90 min. distance from the city you will reach the very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92). MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS Lagkadas Spa: Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki tel.: 23940 22.221 website: www.loutralagada.gr Nea Apollonia Spa: tel.: 23930 41.207 (Town Hall), 23930 41.510, 23930 42.151 (Spa facility) Souroti Spring (where natural mineral water is bottled): Location: Souroti, Thessaloniki tel.: 23960 41.182 (name of bottling company: Souroti A.E.), website: www.souroti.gr) Mud Therapy Spa Centre (Pikrolimni): Xylokeratia, Kilkis tel.: 23410 29.971-3 website: www.pikrolimnispa.gr TRANSPORT Buses. The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Chalkidiki, known for its stunning beaches and vibrant atmosphere, is a fantastic destination for a weekend getaway from Thessaloniki. Here are some popular beaches to consider:

1. **Kassandra Peninsula**: This is the most developed and popular area among tourists. Beaches like **Sani Beach** and **Kalithea Beach** are known for their crystal-clear waters and lively beach bars. Kassandra is approximately 80 km from Thessaloniki, making it about a 1-1.5 hour drive.

2. **Sithonia Peninsula**: Renowned for its natural beauty, Sithonia offers beautiful beaches such as **Vourvourou** and **Kavourotripes**. These beaches are less crowded and perfect for relaxation and swimming. Sithonia is around 100 km from Thessaloniki, taking about 1.5-2 hours by car.

3. **Athos Peninsula**: While primarily known for its monastic community, Athos also has beautiful beaches like **Ouranoupoli**. The area is more tranquil and offers a unique experience. Athos is approximately 120 km from Thessaloniki, which translates to about a 2-hour drive.

4. **Asprovalta Beach**: Located about 70 km from Thessaloniki, Asprovalta features a long sandy beach awarded the Blue Flag for cleanliness. It’s a great spot for beach volleyball and water sports, making it ideal for a fun day out.

5. **Nea Vrasna Beach**: Just a bit further than Asprovalta, Nea Vrasna is also about 75 km from Thessaloniki. It’s known for its family-friendly atmosphere and beautiful sandy shores.

These beaches not only offer picturesque views perfect for Instagram but also provide opportunities to interact with locals and enjoy the vibrant summer culture of Greece. Whether you prefer lively beach bars or serene spots, Chalkidiki has something for every traveler.
reference: The very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. These beaches are known for their stunning scenery and are a great destination for swimming and relaxation.

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH.
